sections.title: Death, Idolatry, and the Significance of the Resurrection

verses.text: Once the agreement was settled, Lysias made his way back to the king, while the Jewish people resumed tending their farms.
verses.comment: This verse provides important historical context that connects to the aftermath of peace negotiations in chapter 11.

verses.text: Yet certain regional officials—Timothy, Apollonius son of Gennaeus, Hieronymus, Demophon, and also Nicanor who governed Cyprus—refused to let the Jews rest in peace.
verses.comment: Lists adversaries who persisted in persecuting the Jewish community following the peace agreement.

verses.text: The people of Joppa committed a wicked act: they invited the Jews living among them—men, women, and children—to board boats they had supplied, pretending there was no harm intended.
verses.comment: Marks a turn in narrative describing Joppa's treachery against Jews in their city.

verses.text: This invitation was approved by a public vote in Joppa. Unaware of the danger, the Jews joined the voyage seeking peaceful relations. But once at sea, the people of Joppa cast them overboard, drowning at least two hundred.
verses.comment: The mass killing described here reveals the depth of betrayal and animosity toward the Jewish residents.

verses.text: Upon hearing of this brutality against his fellow Jews, Judas immediately gave commands to his fighters.
verses.comment: Judas Maccabeus responds swiftly to the massacre, showing leadership and solidarity.

verses.text: Turning to God, the just judge, he led an assault on the murderers of his kinsmen. He set the port on fire at night, burned their ships, and slew all who had tried fleeing to the harbor.
verses.comment: Judas' vengeance is presented as both action and prayer, underscoring faith and justice themes.

verses.text: However, seeing that Joppa’s gates were shut, he withdrew, planning to return later to eradicate the entire city.
verses.comment: Judas’ intention for future retribution highlights his resolve and ongoing conflict.

verses.text: Soon, Judas learned that the people of Jamnia were plotting likewise to destroy the Jews living among them.
verses.comment: Describes continuity of threat to Jewish communities in neighboring cities.

verses.text: So Judas attacked Jamnia at night, setting fire to the harbor and burning the fleet. The blaze was so intense that its glow could be seen all the way in Jerusalem, some thirty miles away.
verses.comment: The visual impact of the fire underscores the significance of Judas’ victory and its reach.

verses.text: As they marched from there, and had covered more than a mile, they were ambushed by a force of at least five thousand Arabs with five hundred horsemen.
verses.comment: Details the sudden attack, emphasizing numbers and military threat.

verses.text: After an intense fight, Judas and his companions, aided by God, prevailed. The defeated nomads pleaded for peace, offering livestock and support to the Jews.
verses.comment: Shows the link between divine aid and military victory; illustrates diplomacy following battle.

verses.text: Judas recognized they could be valuable allies, so he accepted their offer of peace. After being assured of their promises, the Arabs returned to their tents.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Judas’ wisdom in forming tactical alliances.

verses.text: Judas next attacked a town called Caspin, strongly fortified with earthworks and walls, and occupied by various non-Jewish people.
verses.comment: Caspin’s defenses and mixed population illustrate the scope of Judas’ campaigns.

verses.text: From behind their walls and with ample supplies, the inhabitants acted arrogantly toward Judas and his men, mocking and uttering blasphemous insults.
verses.comment: Highlights both military and spiritual opposition from non-Jews inside Caspin.

verses.text: But Judas and his army cried out to the mighty Lord of the universe, who toppled Jericho in Joshua’s day without siege engines or battering rams, and they charged fiercely at Caspin’s walls.
verses.comment: Invokes God’s power in Israel’s history as inspiration for their present assault.

verses.text: By God’s will they captured the town, killing so many that blood seemed to overflow into a nearby lake, which was a quarter mile wide.
verses.comment: The imagery of the lake running with blood communicates the scale and severity of the victory.

verses.text: After traveling ninety-five miles from there, they reached Charax, to visit the Jews known as Toubiani.
verses.comment: Documents the scope and reach of the campaign, noting Jewish communities in the diaspora.

verses.text: Timothy was not found in that area, having already withdrawn without success, though he had left behind a powerful garrison at one location.
verses.comment: A brief strategic update, clarifying the movement of a main adversary.

verses.text: Dositheus and Sosipater, serving as captains under Judas, launched an attack, destroying the entire garrison Timothy had stationed there—over ten thousand men.
verses.comment: Records an important military victory by two of Judas’ commanders.

verses.text: Meanwhile, Judas organized his army into divisions, assigned leaders to each, and hurried in pursuit of Timothy, who had one hundred twenty thousand foot soldiers and two thousand five hundred horsemen with him.
verses.comment: Gives insight into his tactical planning and Timothy’s formidable force.

verses.text: Learning of Judas’ approach, Timothy sent his wives, children, and provisions to a secure spot called Carnaim, knowing it was difficult to besiege because the entryways were so narrow.
verses.comment: Shows the defensive efforts and strategic relocation by Timothy.

verses.text: But as Judas’ first division marched forward, terror from the One who sees everything swept through the enemy. In their panic, they fled in all directions, often wounding each other or impaling themselves on their own swords.
verses.comment: Reflects belief in divine intervention causing chaos among enemies.

verses.text: Judas pursued their retreat with full force, striking down the wicked and slaying as many as thirty thousand.
verses.comment: Displays the ruthlessness of the campaign and the large scale of casualties.

verses.text: Timothy himself was captured by Dositheus, Sosipater, and their men. He cunningly begged to be released unharmed, since he claimed to be holding the parents and some brothers of his captors—threatening to show them no mercy.
verses.comment: Describes Timothy’s craftiness and the desperation in wartime negotiations.

verses.text: After repeatedly assuring them with solemn oaths that he would safely return their relatives, they let Timothy go, putting the safety of their families first.
verses.comment: Shows merciful restraint, motivated by concern for family members.

verses.text: After this, Judas launched an attack on Carnaim and on the temple of Atargatis, killing twenty-five thousand people.
verses.comment: Highlights the destruction of pagan worship centers and large-scale violence.

verses.text: Once those enemies were routed and destroyed, Judas marched on Ephron, a fortified city inhabited by people of all backgrounds, and home to Lysias. Strong young men manned the walls, mounting a robust defense with abundant siege weapons and projectiles.
verses.comment: Details Ephron’s strategic and defensive strength as an obstacle in Judas’ campaign.

verses.text: But the Jews called on the Lord, ruler over all, who shatters his enemies with power. They captured the city and killed about twenty-five thousand inhabitants.
verses.comment: Demonstrates both the efficacy of prayer and the totality of the conquest.

verses.text: Departing from there, they made their way quickly to Scythopolis, located seventy-five miles from Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Narrates the further movement of the army into another key city.

verses.text: When Jews living there testified to the kindness and goodwill shown to them by the residents of Scythopolis, especially during difficult times,
verses.comment: Demonstrates the presence of allies and good interrelations in certain locales.

verses.text: Judas and his companions thanked the people, urging them to continue showing favor to their nation. Then, with the festival of weeks drawing near, they headed up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Celebration of Pentecost anchors the narrative in the Jewish religious calendar.

verses.text: After the feast known as Pentecost, they quickly moved against Gorgias, the commander of Idumea.
verses.comment: Marks transition from religious observance to military campaign.

verses.text: Gorgias advanced with three thousand infantry and four hundred cavalry.
verses.comment: Provides precise details of the enemy’s force size in the forthcoming clash.

verses.text: During the ensuing battle, a few Jewish soldiers were killed.
verses.comment: Briefly acknowledges Jewish losses in the fight.

verses.text: Dositheus, a soldier from Bacenor’s unit and a mighty warrior on horseback, managed to seize Gorgias by his cloak and tried to drag him away alive. But a Thracian cavalryman charged and cut off Dositheus’ arm, allowing Gorgias to escape and reach Marisa.
verses.comment: Dramatic scene emphasizing hand-to-hand combat and near capture.

verses.text: As Esdris and his troops were becoming exhausted after fighting fiercely, Judas called on the Lord to stand by them as both ally and leader in battle.
verses.comment: Centers the narrative on faith and divine partnership in warfare.

verses.text: Judas gave the battle shout in their ancestral language, singing hymns as he unexpectedly charged against Gorgias’s troops and put them to flight.
verses.comment: Combines ritual, language, and surprise attack—indicative of Jewish identity and strategy.

verses.text: Afterward, Judas assembled his men at Adullam. As the Sabbath approached, they purified themselves according to tradition and observed the sacred day there.
verses.comment: Reflects continued observance of Jewish religious obligations even during military crisis.
verses.sectionHeader: Death, Idolatry, and the Significance of the Resurrection

verses.text: The following day, as was now necessary, Judas and his men went to collect the bodies of fallen comrades and bring them home for burial alongside their ancestors.
verses.comment: Emphasizes reverence for the dead and burial customs in Jewish tradition.

verses.text: Beneath each fallen man's tunic, they discovered amulets from the idols of Jamnia—objects forbidden by Jewish law. It became obvious that this was why these men had perished.
verses.comment: Links the defeat of the dead with violation of the Torah’s prohibition of idolatry.

verses.text: Consequently, all praised the Lord’s ways—the just Judge who brings hidden things to light.
verses.comment: Stresses God’s character both in judgment and revelation.

verses.text: They turned to earnest prayer, asking that the wrong committed would be completely wiped away. The noble Judas urged everyone to steer clear of sin, having seen for themselves what befell those who had gone astray.
verses.comment: This verse teaches the importance of repentance and vigilance against sin.

verses.text: Judas also collected donations from every man, totaling two thousand silver drachmas, and sent the money to Jerusalem as a sin offering. In this, he acted well and honorably, keeping in mind the resurrection of the dead.
verses.comment: Evidence of belief in the resurrection and intercessory acts for the dead—an important doctrinal point.

verses.text: For if he hadn’t expected that those who had died would rise again, it would have been pointless and foolish to pray for the dead.
verses.comment: A theological argument supporting prayers for the dead, based on belief in resurrection.

verses.text: But since he was looking forward to the wonderful reward awaiting those who die faithfully, this was a virtuous and devout thing to do. That’s why he made atonement for the dead, so they might be freed from their sin.
verses.comment: The closing verse sums up the theological foundation for atonement and hope of forgiveness beyond death.
